intro: Gilia aggregata f. maculata, commonly known as the spotted gilia, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the evening primrose family (Onagraceae) and is characterized by its showy, violet to purple flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is often found in desert or semi-arid environments. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while its stems are slender and often branched. The spotted gilia is known for its ability to thrive in harsh conditions, making it a resilient and adaptable species.
